sentence.text: But Holland 's particular trademark is a cute and cloying sentimentality , with pathos laid on thick .
Joy Morton incorporated his Morton Salt company in Chicago in 1910 , based on a business dating from 1848 , and his ` umbrella girl " trademark is still familiar on American dining tables .
His trademark is an endless supply of baggy designer suits , but his modernity belies an old fashioned belief in diligence and grasp of detail .
His trademark is his early-'60s reverse-body Gibson Firebird , a guitar acquired more by chance than design …
It makes a stronger seam of two panels and is a trademark of some of the best sewn , professionally-made kites .
When long hair was the trademark of the hippy and the dropout , it is to be expected that an anti-hippy movement should adopt short hair .
THe gull wing doors , right , are a trademark of the range and offer superb access to the interior .
The researchers relied on the ability of the material to repel a magnetic field , a trademark of superconductors .
Johnstone 's size was both his trademark and a source of torment .
Once both hands are across , the feet will inevitably follow , smearing cautiously on another of those rounded breaks that are a trademark hereabouts .
But attention to detail is the director 's trademark .
Since the choked delivery has become one of his trademarks , it 's not a little disconcerting to hear a smooth vocal style accompanying his post- Graduate body movements .
` You Make Me Feel ( Mighty Real ) " sang Sylvester with that glorious lightness of spirit that was his trademark , encapsulating our lack , our need , our desire .
High-handedness and arrogance are their trademarks , as you saw last night at the governor 's palace .
Blood and Uzis more than samba and sequins are their trademark today .
The instantly and universally recognisable white face of the famous Hereford is its trademark , which it always passes to its offspring .
